div.p:
There is some
probability of an
expedition being
sent up the Zambesi.
A deputation from
the British Association
has formed a com-
mittee which met at the Royal
Society's apartments
on Saturday last
General Sabine, Dr
Lloyd, Sir H. Rawlinson
Sir R. Murchison
MacGregor Laird
& Dr Robinson were
present. They are
to be strengthened by
memorials from
the chambers of com-
merce of Liverpool
ManchesterLeeds
& Birmingham &c.
& an interview with
Lord Clarendon will
come off soon. There
is therefore some
probability of success
The object being to
survey the Zambesi
and get full inform-
ation respecting the
natural productions
of the new countries.

My Object in writing
you is rather a selfish
one. I believe you &
I came through Graham's
hands as well as
Dr Lyon Playfair
Dr Thomson
Prof. G. Wilson
James Young our
under or superintendent
I confess to having
a feeling of partiality
to that squad and though
I cannot indulge a
ray of hope that you
will join us as there
no body in the wide
world I should like
better than you I
am constrained to
say even without
hope - I can't go
farther, but possibly
if it comes to selection
you will be able to
recommend a sensible
good tempered fellow
though you don't come yourself
I don't suppose I shall
have anything to do
in the selection but
I may have a power
of veto, probably
your father will
be applied to. Between
ourselves I don't
want a German.
Do you see how
these Schlagentweits
are hawked about
as if neither you
nor Thomson had
ever been on the
Hymalayas.
We shall send over
that precious book
that gave me
such a deal of
bother before long.

I hope Mrs H.
recovered nicely.
I have been spouting
at different places
but am thankful
to say that work
is now done. I go
to Portugal soon
And am Ever yours
